history.content: Wouldn't recommend taking CS 61C during recruiting season

children.subject: Forgot to mention, 16A labs do take at least 2 hours a week. 61C labs take 2-4 hours. They add up, and can be quite annoying. Also, 61C labs can take 5+ hours if you're stuck.

I found 186 and 61C to have same amount of work. 61C has more assignments, but the time spent balances out. 16A was probably the lowest workload i've ever had in a class at Berkeley. Problem sets with 170 took me 2-5 hours a week, but it generally takes a lot longer for most people.

I do not recommend those 3 classes, especially if you intend on recruiting.

Take 170 and 160. Worst case, if you're dying on a problem set, your friends can help you figure out the answers. For 61C, it's a lot more difficult to get help, especially since friends can't really help with your entire logic, and they can't debug. In addition, 61C just has a lot more busy work(weekly labs, gradescope hw, coding assignments, projects).

However, 61C opens up the doors to upper division courses like 161 and 162 (186, 168 do not need 61C), so in case you're rushing to take those classes, switch to 61C and 160. Get a really good and reliable partner for lab and projects, it will make your life a lot easier in 61C.

history.content: For reference, I am currently taking 186, 184, EE16a + research and finding it very manageable.
history.subject: Thoughts on taking 61c, 170, 160 together?

history.content: For reference, I am currently taking 186, 184, and EE16a and finding it very manageable.
